results.title: Ivan the Terrible [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: Mosfilm, Central Cinema Studios and Sergei Eisenstein
results.brief_description: Ivan the Terrible part one is Eisenstein’s boldest and most successful experiment in stylisation. It draws upon the other arts - Wagnerian opera, Marinsky ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre. Ivan’s personal life is interwoven with the themes of his drive for empire and his alliance with the merchant class against the aristocracy. This is the first part of a trilogy; the second part is dominated by cloak and dagger intrigue; the final part, which was to be in colour, was designed but not filmed. Cinematography by Edouard Tisse and Andrei Moskvin. Music by Sergei Prokofieff. Cast includes Nikolai Cherkasov, Ludmilla Tselikovskaya, Seraphina Birman, Pyotr Kadochnikov. In russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Ivan Groznyi = Ivan the Terrible. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Central Cinema Studios, Alma-Ata Studios and Sergei Eisenstein
results.brief_description:
The first two parts of Eisenstein’s intended trilogy on on the unification of Russia under the 16th century Czar. In the trilogy Eisenstein planned to show the inner struggle of the first Czar of Russia and founder of the Russian state, in his effort to consolidate the unity of the realm against its enemies at home - the boyars or feudal noblemen - and neighbouring powers. Ivan the Terrible part I is Eisenstein’s boldest and most successful experiment in stylisation drawing upon other arts - Wagnerian opera, Marinsky ballet and Japanese Kabuki theatre - which he had begun in ‘Alexander Nevsky’. Ivan’s personal life is interwoven with the themes of his drive for empire and his alliance with the merchant class against the aristocracy. Part II, the last film Eisenstein made, is dominated by cloak-and-dagger intrigue. It was completed in 1946 but not released until 1959. It takes up the story of Ivan the Terrible upon his return to Moscow from Alexandrov. The complex story is full of intrigue, high level political in-fighting, family resentment and suspicion, and assassination plot, executions and murder in the cathedral. Two reels of the original were filmed in colour. The banquet scene towards the end of the film was Eisenstein’s first use of colour stock. Part 3 which was to be in colour, was designed but never filmed. Pts. I and II also available separately on VHS. Pt. I also available separately on 16mm.

Credits: Director, writer, Sergei Eisenstein ; photography, Andrei Moskvin, Edouard Tisse ; music, Sergei Prokofiev.
Cast: Nikolai Cherkassov, Ludmila Tselikovskaya, Serafima Birman, Ludmila Tselikovskaya.

results.title: Ivan Durrant (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Australian artist Ivan Durrant is infamously known for killing a cow and depositing it at the entrance of the National Gallery of Victoria in the late 60’s. It was to accompany another of his well-known art pieces, “The Butcher Shop”, housed at the gallery in their permanent collection. One of Australia’s most accomplished photo-realist artists, Durrant’s paintings are featured alongside his sculptural works in this documentary. His subjects stem from childhood memories and mostly centre around images of cattle and pigs, with man’s violence against animals featuring in more esoteric ways in works like, “the quality meat show”. Looking broadly, his work is preoccupied with perception and how we choose to box or see things, or refuse to consider the more difficult truths about ourselves. Contained within this video are some images of cruelty against animals, with excerpts from Durrant’s film “Chopping Blocks” that is particularly disturbing in content. Please note: both U-matic and VHS copy have poor quality sound.

results.title: Ivan and Abraham = Moi Ivan, toi Abraham [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Hatchette Premiere, UGC Images, Films Balenciaga, Rene Cleitman, Jean-Luc Ormieres and Yolande Zauberman
results.brief_description: This beautifully directed and photographed debut feature film by Franco-Polish filmmaker, Yoldande Zauberman, is set in a 1930s Polish shtetl, or small Jewish community, during a time of impending religious and political tensions leading up to Hitler’s invasion of Poland. It tells of a unique and special friendship between two young boys, Abraham (Roma Alexandrovitch), a nine year-old Jewish boy and Ivan (Sacha Iakovlev), a fourteen year-old Catholic boy, and their determination to remain best friends as religious prejudices begin to surface in the Polish community and within Abraham’s own family. When Abraham’s grandfather tries to stop the boys from seeing one another, they decide to runaway together. Added to this family drama is the alienation between Abraham’s teenage sister, Rachel (Marina Lipkina) and their father, who disapproves of Rachel’s relationship with Aaron (Vladimir Machkov), a young Communist activist. Aaron and Rachel also take flight to escape the prejudices and intolerances and to seek out Abraham and Ivan. The film focuses on these four young outcasts, their relationships and the drama of living in uncertain times. Filmed evocatively in black and white with quite an impressive young cast, “Ivan and Abraham” captures the essence of life between the Wars in Eastern Europe and the intolerances which existed, not only religiously, but politically and ethnically. Cast also includes Alexandre Kaliaguine, Helene Lapiower, Rolan Bykov, Zinovi Guerdt. In Yiddish, Polish, Russian and Gypsy dialect with English subtitles. (Awards: Cannes, 1993; Moscow, 1993)
results.title_for_label: Ivan and Abraham = Moi Ivan, toi Abraham [Widescreen] [NTSC]

results.title: Ivan's childhood = Ivanovo Detstvo [DVD]
results.creator_credit: G Natanson, Andrei Tarkovsky and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Tarkovsky’s prize-winning debut feature is an extraordinarily moving view of war and revenge. Twelve year-old Ivan is determined to avenge his mother’s death, and he joins a Russian regiment as a scout. His ability to slip through enemy lines more easily than an adult makes him useful to the army, but, as his missions become increasingly dangerous, it is decided that he must be removed from the front line. Ivan resists and convinces his commanding officers to allow him to carry out one last expedition. The monochrome photography depicts Ivan’s war in a series of memorable sequences, and contributes to making this film one of cinema’s great statements on war. Also available on VHS [311666].

results.title: Itzhak Perlman: Beethoven violin concerto in D, op. 61
results.brief_description: This video recording of Beethoven’s violin concerto in D, op. 61 was produced in the studio and features the exquisite music of Israeli born violin virtuoso, Itzhak Perlman accompanied by the Philharmonia Orchestra (leader, Carl Pini) and world-renowned conductor, Carlo Maria Giulini.

results.title: Its water cycle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth”.
Shows clouds massing and evaporating, ice crystals growing under photomicrography, and air and water under varying pressures in a plastic box, in order to illustrate the hydrologic or evaporation-condensation-precipitation cycle.

results.title: Its oceans
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth”.
A comprehensive study, revealing the changing pattern of the ocean’s surface, the living and non-living things in the waters, the nature of the ocean floor, and the influence of the oceans on man. The roles of modern scientists - oceanographers, marine biologists and others - as they work to gain more knowledge of the earth’s vast, deep oceans.

results.title: Ithal Damat = Imported groom
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Huseyin Duman and ACMI
results.brief_description: Huseyin Damat left Turkey for Australia to meet and marry his wife. Although he was sad to leave his family behind, his journey here was an eventful one, especially when he discovered he was on the same flight as Swedish super group ABBA.

results.title: Ithaca
results.brief_description: A short 3D computer animation depicts a formation of ufos flying amongst the pyramids. A tour of some of the natural land forms around the world, we see mountains form, marbled rock formations and islands over a psychadelic sea. The ufo’s playfully fly amongst the various forms as if celebrating and surveying their creations.
